L1_summary_of_paper: This study develops and empirically tests a dynamic process model of competitive interaction, conceptualizing strategy as an ordered sequence of competitive actions (‘competitive attacks’) over time. Using data on thousands of competitive actions among the top two firms in 16 U.S. industries (1987–1993), the paper defines competitive aggressiveness through four attack dimensions: volume (number of actions per attack), duration (time span of attack), complexity (diversity of action types), and unpredictability (variation in action sequences across attacks). The model specifies antecedents—top management team (TMT) heterogeneity, past performance, organizational slack, and industry context (growth, concentration, entry barriers)—and links these to attack characteristics. It then relates attack characteristics to market share gains, positing linear effects for volume and duration, and curvilinear (increasing) effects for complexity and unpredictability. Findings show that TMT heterogeneity increases attack complexity but reduces duration; past good performance reduces duration; slack increases volume and duration; and competition-buffered industries dampen aggressiveness. On outcomes, higher volume and longer duration attacks improve market share, while complexity and unpredictability show U-shaped rather than predicted monotonic effects. The paper contributes to competitive dynamics by introducing the sequence-level analysis of competitive behavior, integrates upper echelons and industry-structure perspectives, and refines understanding of how internal and external factors shape and constrain sustained competitive aggressiveness.
A1_citation: Ferrier, W. J. (2001). Navigating the competitive landscape: The drivers and consequences of competitive aggressiveness. Academy of Management Journal, 44(4), 858–877.
B4_contribution_type: Other: Extension of competitive dynamics to sequence-level analysis
C3_metric_detail: Uncertainty referenced as strategic time decision-making complexity and unpredictability; not directly measured.
D2_identification: Other: Random-effects (PROC MIXED) with AR(1); no causal identification
D5_data_sources: Dun & Bradstreet Reference Book of Corporate Managements
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Relies on media-coded competitive actions, potential measurement bias; no public data/code.
G1_construct_mapping_note: Competitive attack dimensions can map onto aggressiveness and complexity constructs in repertoire research; volume/duration align with activity rate measures; unpredictability aligns with strategic variability constructs.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: Internal (TMT, slack, past performance) and external (industry structure) drivers jointly shape sustained aggressiveness.
Sustained and voluminous attacks overwhelm rivals and improve market share.
Complexity and unpredictability effects may be non-linear, with performance gains only beyond certain thresholds.
NA_reason_if_any: Empirical panel study testing process model hypotheses.
I1_mechanism_statements: Heterogeneous TMTs possess greater cognitive diversity, enabling more complex attacks but reducing duration due to slower consensus.
Good past performance fosters complacency, reducing sustained aggressiveness.
Slack resources enable higher-volume and longer-duration attacks.
Competition-buffered industries lower motivation for aggressive sequences.
High volume and duration attacks overwhelm rivals, delaying responses and increasing market share.
Complexity and unpredictability in sequences slow rivals’ responses, potentially boosting market share when above certain thresholds.
J1_main_findings_summary: TMT heterogeneity positively relates to attack complexity and negatively to duration.
Good past performance reduces attack duration.
Organizational slack increases attack volume and duration.
Industry entry barriers and concentration reduce certain aggressiveness dimensions.
Attack volume and duration positively impact market share gain.
Attack complexity and unpredictability have U-shaped, not purely positive, relationships with market share.
K1_contribution_summary: The paper extends competitive dynamics research by conceptualizing and measuring competitive strategy as sequences of competitive actions, introducing four dimensions of competitive aggressiveness and linking them to both firm- and industry-level antecedents and market share outcomes. It integrates upper echelons, learning, and industry structure perspectives, highlighting both enabling and constraining forces shaping sustained competitive behavior, and finds that while volume and duration enhance performance, complexity and unpredictability yield non-linear effects.
